title: The U.S. Open Won’t Have a Repeat Champion After Naomi Osaka Goes Down
text:
The U.S. Open won’t have a repeat champion this year.

Women’s No. 1 seed Naomi Osaka fell to No. 13 seed Belinda Bencic on Monday, a day after men’s No. 1 seed Novak Djokovic retired against Stan Wawrinka due to a shoulder injury. Both Osaka and Djokovic are defending champions.

Osaka clearly wasn’t right during the match. Since the start of the Open, she has worn a brace on her left knee. Late in the match, Osaka gingerly moved her left foot when she ran to the left.

“I hurt my knee in Cincinnati, but it’s getting better,” Osaka said. “I just needed to take a painkiller.”

In her 7-6, 6-4 victory, Bencic had 29 winners and just 12 unforced errors, while Osaka had 26 winners and 21 unforced errors.

Belinda Bencic celebrates her win against Naomi Osaka. Photo: Javier Rojas/Pi/Zuma Press

Prior to Monday’s match, Osaka, 21, finally seemed like she was in a solid place since she lost quickly at the French Open and Wimbledon. In the third round here, Osaka dumped Cori “Coco” Gauff in a prime-time matchup, and then she comforted Gauff when she was overwhelmed during the post-match festivities.

”It’s something I have learned over the summer that even if you aren’t playing your best, you’re going to play people who are going to play their best. You have to figure out how to win those matches,” Osaka said on Monday. “I think on that side I have a lot of growing up to do.”

Now that Osaka is gone, Serena Williams is the only player still in the tournament who has won a Grand Slam title. The draw appears favorable for Williams, with No. 5 Elina Svitolina as the only other remaining player in the top 10. Bencic will play against Donna Vekic, who has reached her first major quarterfinal.

Williams, the eighth seed, is a six-time U.S. Open champion and aiming to win her 24th Grand Slam title, which would tie her with Margaret Court for the most in the sport. Williams hasn’t won a Slam since the Australian Open in 2017, although she has played in three Slam finals since coming back from giving birth to her daughter in Sept. 2017. She has battled injuries to her ankle, knee and back for most of this season.

Ashleigh Barty, who lost to No. 18 Wang Quiang in the fourth round, will take over the No. 1 ranking from Osaka after the tournament.

The loss by Djokovic, who has won four of the past five Grand Slams, increases the possibility of a long-awaited showdown between Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal at the U.S. Open. The longtime rivals have met in the finals of the other three Slams but have never played in New York. Nadal plays 2014 U.S. Open champion Marin Cilic for a spot in the last eight on Monday night.

Stan Wawrinka and Novak Djokovic embrace after Djokovic’s retirement from the match on Sunday night. Photo: Elena Leoni/Zuma Press

Federer routed David Goffin in straight sets on Sunday to advance to his 56th career Grand Slam quarterfinal and will face unseeded Grigor Dimitrov on Tuesday.

Federer, 38, spent time on Sunday reflecting on his remarkable success and that of Williams, who turns 38 later this month.

“We went about it different ways, totally different backgrounds and all that,” Federer said. “But because we know we can still beat the best, win the biggest tournaments, it’s so worthwhile to stay there and see if you can go back to these emotions, see if you can do it at a later stage in your career.”

Write to Jim Chairusmi at jim.chairusmi@wsj.com
description: The U.S. Open won’t have a repeat champion this year, with both Naomi Osaka and Novak Djokovic going down.
